questions.text: Where is the headquarters of the following organization located?
questions.solution:
The given image is the logo of the World Health Organization, WHO that has its headquarters located in Geneva, Switzerland.

WHO is a specialized, non-political health agency of the United Nations. It came into force on the 7th of April 1948. Its prime objective is the attainment by all people of the highest level of health. The structure of the WHO comprises the World Health Assembly, the Executive Board, and the Secretariat. 

 The responsibility of the WHO is in the following broad areas:

  1. Prevention and control of specific diseases
  2. Development of comprehensive health services
  3. Family health
  4. Environmental health
  5. Health statistics
  6. Biomedical research
  7. Health literature and information
  8. Co-operation with other international organizations

The headquarters of regional offices of WHO are:

  • The Southeast Asian regional office (SEARO) is in New Delhi, India
  • The African regional office is in Brazzaville, Republic of Congo.
  • The American regional office is in Washington D. C., USA.
  • The European regional head office is in Copenhagen, Denmark.
  • The Eastern Mediterranean regional office is in Alexandria, Egypt.
  • The Western Pacific regional office is in Manila, Philippines.

The headquarters of other important organizations are:

  • The headquarters of UNICEF and UNDP is in New York, USA.
  • The headquarters of the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) is in Rome, Italy.

Note: Other organizations that have headquarters in Geneva are the International Labor Organization (ILO) and the International Red Cross Society.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman who recently lost her only son wants to conceive again. She visited the genetic counseling center as she was worried about her advanced age. What is the risk of giving birth to a baby with Down's syndrome in this woman?
questions.solution:
The risk of giving birth to a baby with Down's syndrome at the time of conception in this lady who is 45 years old is 1 in 50.

Down’s syndrome is an autosomal disorder. It was described by Langdon Down in 1866. It is also called trisomy 21 or mongolism. The clinical features of Down's syndrome seen in older children are:

  • Short stature
  • Small round head
  • Narrow tilted eye slits
  • Mal-formed ears
  • Short broad hands
  • Lax limbs
  • Mental retardation
  • Congenital abnormalities like cardiac defects and atresia of the alimentary tract.

The frequency of Down's syndrome increases with rising maternal age. The risk of a woman who is 20 is 1 in 3000 but that of a woman who is 45 is 1 in 50.

It seems to be unaffected by the age of the father.

Note: Genetic counseling: It can either be prospective or retrospective. Prospective genetic counseling refers to the prevention of disease by the prevention or reduction of heterozygous marriage like in sickle cell anemia or thalassemia. Retrospective genetic counseling means that the hereditary disorder has already occurred in the family and methods like contraception, pregnancy termination or sterilization are to be used to avoid any serious health disorder in the unborn baby. 

Methods of early diagnosis and treatment are early detection of genetic carriers, prenatal diagnosis, screening of newborn infants, and recognizing pre-clinical cases.

questions.text:
A researcher is preparing to do a cohort study in the gastroenterology wards to determine the association of H. pylori with inflammatory bowel disease. Which of the following are true regarding the advantages of this study?
  1. Attrition is low
  2. Incidence can be calculated
  3. Provides a direct estimate of relative risk
  4. Allows study of multiple outcomes from the same exposure
  5. Hawthorne effect is reduced
questions.solution:
Among the given statements, the true statements regarding the advantages of cohort studies are 2, 3, and 4 only.

The advantages of cohort study are the following:

  • The incidence can be calculated.
  • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied simultaneously
  • Provides a direct estimate of relative risk
  • Dose-response ratios can be calculated
  • Bias like misclassification can be minimized

The disadvantages of cohort study are the following:

  • The study of rare diseases is not possible
  • Takes a longer time to complete the study and obtain results
  • Attrition is high. It refers to a reduction in the number of participants in the study. A substantial proportion of the original cohort may be lost due to migration, loss of interest, or non-cooperation.
  • The selection of comparison groups that are representative of the exposed and unexposed segments of the population is a limiting factor
  • Changes in the standard methods or diagnostic criteria of the disease
  • High costs to conduct the study
  • Ethical problems
  • The study tends to alter the behavior of subjects. For example, a study on the association of smoking with lung cancer may lead the study subjects to reduce or quit smoking. This is known as the Hawthorne effect.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

questions.text: After recent floods in a region, the water bodies get grossly contaminated. How much free residual chlorine level in water sources would you recommend after such a disaster?
questions.solution:
The recommended level of free residual chlorine in water sources after floods/natural disasters is >0.5 mg/L.

After a disaster such as a flood, the water bodies are grossly contaminated with sewage and drainage. The mixing of feces in drinking water sources increases the risk of numerous microbial infections. The advisable level of residual chlorine in water bodies after a disaster is more than 0.5 mg/L, and can be as high as 1 mg/L. If the free residual chlorine level is lower than 0.5 mg/liter, the water should be disinfected again. 

Note: Under routine circumstances, the minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/L for one hour.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: A patient with sepsis was transferred to another hospital. Airing and sunning of his room and furniture were done by the hospital staff after the patient left. Which of the following methods was used in this scenario?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, terminal cleaning is used as a cleaning method.

Terminal cleaning is the process of airing and sunning the rooms, furniture, and bedding of a patient who has died or has been shifted to another hospital or after cessation of isolation. The room is cleaned with a detergent or enzyme cleaner by the hospital staff so that a new patient can be admitted to that room. Currently, this method is used in place of terminal disinfection and is considered adequate. 

Routine cleaning is the cleaning of inpatient areas while the patient is staying in the hospital. This aims to provide a visibly clean environment and reduce microbial contamination.

Types of disinfection are:

  • Terminal disinfection is the application of disinfection measures after the patient has died or has been shifted to another hospital or after cessation of isolation. It is rarely done now and has been replaced by terminal cleaning.
  • Concurrent disinfection is the application of disinfection methods after the discharge of infectious material from the body of an infected person or soiling.
  • Precurrent/prophylactic disinfection is the application of preventive measures like pasteurization of milk, chlorination of water, and handwashing.

Disinfection refers to the thermal or chemical destruction of the most recognized pathogenic microorganisms, but not necessarily all microbial forms like bacterial spores.

Cleaning refers to the removal of adherent visible debris from the surfaces, instruments and equipment by a manual or mechanical process to render it safe from further decontamination.

Sodium hypochlorite(0.5-5%) is the best disinfectant for surface blood spills. Hydrogen peroxide can be used for disinfection or sterilization which has largely replaced fumigation. It is also used in plasma sterilization.

Related Pearl: The Spaulding Classification

The Spaulding classification classifies medical devices according to the degree of risk of infection if they are contaminated.

Device

Examples

questions.text: A city has a population of 8,00,000 people. 4000 of them were diagnosed with COVID-19, out of which 100 died. What is the case fatality rate of COVID-19 in this city?
questions.solution:
The case fatality rate of COVID-19 in this city is (100 deaths/4000 cases)×100 = 2.5%

Case fatality rate = Total number of deaths due to a particular disease X 100 / Total number of cases due to the same disease

It represents the killing power of disease and is typically used in acute infectious diseases. Its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is long and variable. The case fatality rate for the same disease may vary in different epidemics because of changes in the agent, host, and environmental factors.

The case fatality rate of COVID-19 according to WHO is, less than 0.1% to over 25%. The estimates of CFR for covid-19 are widely variable from country to country.

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: All the passengers coming to India were screened for COVID-19 at the airport. Which type of screening is done in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The type of screening done for the immigrants to a country is prospective screening. 

Prospective screening is done for disease control. People are examined for the benefit of others. It may lead to an early diagnosis and permit more effective treatment. It also reduces the spread of infectious diseases in the community, thereby reducing the mortality associated with the disease.

Examples of prospective screening:

  • Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as tuberculosis and syphilis to protect the home population
  • Screening for streptococcal infection to prevent rheumatic fever

Other options:

Option A - Prescriptive screening is done for case detection. People are examined for their own benefit. Screening is initiated by medical and public health personnel and is not requested by a patient. It may lead to an early diagnosis of an unrecognized disease. Hence, appropriate treatment can be initiated immediately to arrest disease progression.

Examples of prescriptive screening:

  • Screening of infants for phenylketonuria
  • Screening of school children for visual and auditory defects.

Option B - Multiphasic screening is the combined application of two or more screening tests to a large number of people at one time. It is not cost-effective and has shown no benefit in reducing the morbidity and mortality of the population.

Option D - Selective screening is done in high-risk groups. It is one of the most productive screening tests. Examples include MRI screening of the breast done annually in a 25-year-old woman with a first-degree relative having BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation.

questions.text:
Which of the following are methods of indirect transmission of communicable diseases?
  1. Contact with soil
  2. Droplet nuclei
  3. Fomite borne
  4. Unclean hands and fingers
  5. Transplacental
questions.solution:
Among the given options, droplet nuclei, fomite borne and transmission through unclean hands and fingers are modes of indirect transmission of diseases.

Communicable diseases are classified based on the mode of transmission:

  • Direct:
    • Direct contact (Eg: sexual intercourse)
    • Contact with soil
    • Droplet infection
    • Skin or mucosal inoculation
    • Transplacental 
  • Indirect: 
    • Vehicle-borne
    • Vector-borne
    • Air-borne
      • Droplet nuclei
      • Dust
    • Fomite-borne
    • Unclean hands and fingers

The traditional 5 F's - flies, fingers, fomites, food, and fluids can be used to remember the modes of indirect transmission. Some infectious agents are able to survive in the external environment while maintaining their basic properties of virulence. This is a  requirement for this indirect transmission. 

An important distinction has to be drawn between droplet nuclei infection and droplet infection. The main difference between airborne droplet nuclei and droplet transmission is in the size of infected/contagious particles and whether proximity is required for transmission.

Droplet nuclei/residue from evaporated droplets containing infective microorganisms can result in airborne transmission. The size of these droplet nuclei is <5 μm in diameter, and they can remain suspended in the air for significant periods of time, allowing them to be transmitted over distances >1 m.  There's no need for close proximity or contact. Diseases like chickenpox, measles, tuberculosis, and influenza can spread through airborne transmission.

Droplet transmission occurs when one coughs or sneezes, and contagious droplets from the infected person travel shortly in the air and directly comes in contact with another person's conjunctiva, mouth, or nasal mucosa. The particle size here is >5 μm in diameter. Transmission here requires close proximity and direct contact. Examples of diseases spread via this route include the common cold, diphtheria, and whooping cough.

Related Pearl: Modes of Transmission of Communicable Diseases

Inoculation into skin or mucosa

Vertical (transplacental)

Vehicle-borne

Fomite borne

Unclean hands and finger

questions.text:
Which of the following bio-medical waste materials are disposed off in yellow bags?
  1. Expired drugs
  2. Latex gloves
  3. Placenta
  4. Blood bag
  5. Used pacemaker
questions.solution:
Expired drugs, placenta, and blood bags are disposed of in yellow-colored containers or non-chlorinated plastic bags.

Latex gloves are disposed of in red-colored containers.

Used pacemakers are discarded in blue-colored containers.

questions.text:
Match the following phases of the family cycle with the event that marks its beginning.
Phase Beginning of phase 
1. Contraction A. Marriage
2. Formation B. First spouse dies
3. Dissolution C. Birth of first child
4. Extension D. First child leaves home
questions.solution:
The option that shows the phase of the family cycle correctly matched to its beginning is the one showing 1-D, 2-A, 3-B, 4-C.

Phase Beginning of phase 
1. Contraction D. First child leaves home
2. Formation A. Marriage
3. Dissolution B. First spouse dies
4. Extension C. Birth of first child

 

Related Pearl: The Family as a Social Organization

  • A family is a group of biologically related individuals living together under the same roof and eating from a common kitchen.
  • It is the most primary and basic unit of all societies.
  • The basic and arbitrary model of a family cycle has six phases:

 

Phase

Beginning

End

1

Formation

Marriage

Birth of 1st child

2

Extension

Birth of 1st child

Birth of last child

3

Complete extension

Birth of last child

1st child leaves home

4

Contraction

1st child leaves home

Last child leaves parental home

5

Completed contraction

Last child leaves parental home

Death of 1st spouse

6

Dissolution

Death of 1st spouse

Death of survivor
  • Types of families:
    • A nuclear family or elementary family consists of only the married couple and their offspring while they are dependants.
    • The term new family is applied when nuclear families are younger than 10 years and consist of parents and children.
    • A joint family or extended family consists of a number of married couples and their children who live together in the same household with usually the men being related by blood. All property in joint families is held in common with the family income going into a common pocket. A senior male member is usually the head of the family who makes decisions.
    • A three generation family is one where there are representatives from three different generations in one house.
    • A communal family is one in which all the members play a part in its management.
  • Functions of the family:
    • Residence (patrilocal and matrilocal)
    • Division of labour
    • Reproduction and raising children
    • Socialization and social care
    • Economic functions
  • Problems families are those that lag behind the rest of the community in terms of standard and quality of life of its members.
  • Broken families are those in which the parental or family system has been disrupted by separation, divorce or death.

questions.text:
During a vaccination drive, a 36-year-old pregnant woman with an obstetric score of G4P3L2 comes to get vaccinated. Which of the following vaccines are contraindicated in this woman?
  1. COVID-19
  2. Varicella
  3. Hepatitis A
  4. Rubella
  5. Zoster
questions.solution:
Among the given options, varicella vaccine, rubella vaccine, and zoster vaccine cannot be administered to this patient as they are live vaccines, which are contraindicated in pregnant women.

The live vaccines are contraindicated in pregnancy unless the risk of infection exceeds the risk of harm to the fetus.

Contraindications for live vaccines:

  • Immune deficiency diseases
  • Suppressed immune responses as a result of 
    • Leukaemia
    • Lymphoma
    • Malignancies
    • Corticosteroid therapy
    • Treatment with alkylating agents and antimetabolic agents 
    • Therapeutic radiation
  • Pregnancy

Related Pearl: Types of Vaccines

Type

questions.text:
A man brings his 4-year-old son to the OPD claiming that he was bit by an insect shown in the image below. The child may suffer from which of the following diseases?
  1. Q fever
  2. Rocky Mountain spotted fever
  3. Colorado tick fever
  4. Relapsing fever
  5. Tularaemia
questions.solution:
The given image is of a hard tick. Among the given options, the diseases transmitted by hard ticks are rocky mountain spotted fever, Colorado tick fever, and tularaemia.

Hard ticks are covered by a chitinous shield on their dorsal surface which is called the scutum. They have a head or capitulum present at the anterior end, which is visible from above. 

Diseases transmitted by hard ticks:

  • Tick typhus (Rocky Mountain spotted fever)
  • Viral encephalitis (Russian spring-summer encephalitis)
  • Viral fevers (e.g., Colorado tick fever)
  • Viral hemorrhagic fevers (e.g. Kyasanur Forest disease in India)
  • Tularaemia
  • Tick paralysis
  • Human babesiosis.

Diseases transmitted by soft ticks:

  • Q fever
  • Relapsing fever
  • Kyasanur Forest disease

An image of a soft tick is shown below.

Related Pearl: Ticks

  • The two types of ticks are hard ticks and soft ticks.
  • The general morphology of ticks includes an oval-shaped body, four pairs of legs, and no antennae.
  Hard tick Soft tick
Scutum A chitinous shield that covers the entire back in males. Females have a small portion in the front. Absent.
Head Situated at the anterior end. Lies on the underside of the body (ventrally). Not visible from above.
Eggs Several hundreds or thousands laid at once Laid in batches of 20 – 100 over a long period
Nymphal stages One Five
Habits Cannot withstand starvation; feed night and day. Can withstand starvation for more than a year.
Vectors for Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, tularemia, Kyasanur forest disease, babesiosis, tick paralysis. Ixodes type transmits Lyme disease. Soft tick is a reservoir for Q fever and a vector for relapsing fever.
Life span Short Longer
Habits Always found on their hosts. They hide in cracks and crevices during the day and come out to feed during the night.
  • Insecticidal control of ticks includes DDT, chlordane, dieldrin, lindane, malathion, and toxaphene. Environmental control and protection of workers must also be done to prevent disease transmission from ticks.

Related Pearl: Arthropod- borne diseases

questions.text: A 53-year-old painter comes to the OPD with constipation and foot drop. On investigation, peripheral blood smear shows the following finding. Toxicity of which of the following agents is this patient suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario shows a painter with constipation, foot drop and basophilic stippling. He is most likely suffering from lead toxicity. 

Lead exerts its toxic action by combining with the SH-group of enzymes involved in porphyrin synthesis and carbohydrate metabolism. It disrupts normal membrane permeability and causes potassium leakage in RBCs. Symptoms of lead toxicity include:

Clinical features of lead toxicity:

  • Abdominal colic
  • Loss of appetite, obstipation, constipation
  • Anemia (stippling of red cells)
  • Wrist drop or foot drop
  • Blue-line on the gums known as Burtonian line
  • Headache
  • Delirium, confusion
  • Insomnia

The most common mode of industrial lead poisoning (plumbism) is due to inhalation of fumes and dust of lead. Lesser common modes include ingestion of small quantities of lead trapped in the upper respiratory tract, ingestion due to contaminated hands, and absorption through the skin (only organic lead). Lead poisoning is a notifiable and compensable disease in India.

Periodic examination of workers must be done and atmosphere lead concentration must be kept <2mg/cubic meter at the workspace. Handwashing before eating and prohibition of taking food in workplaces is essential. Measurement of Coproporphyrin (CPU) in urine is a useful screening test. D-penicillamine is used as a chelating agent for treatment.

Other options: Mercury (option A) poisoning causes mainly CNS dysfunction with features like tremors, decreased peripheral nerve conduction, depression, anxiety, etc. Inhalation of fumes may cause pneumonitis.

Copper (Option C) toxicity causes GI symptoms mainly like abdominal pain, hematemesis, melena, jaundice, and a characteristic blue-green material in emesis or stool. Altered mentation, depression, and fatigue might be seen.

Arsenic (Option D) toxicity symptoms differ in acute and chronic toxicities. Acute toxicity presents with vomiting, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea whereas chronic toxicity features include pigmentation changes, skin lesions and hard patches on the palms and soles of the feet (hyperkeratosis).

Related Pearl: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

Lead Toxicity
Source of exposure

Occupational exposure

Lead paint
Route of absorption

Children - GI tract

Adults - Respiratory tract
Mechanism of action
  • Binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits
    • ALA dehydratase
    • Ferrochelatase
  • Inhibits pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase
  • Competes with calcium
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

GI tract, Bone marrow, Peripheral nerves
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS, Kidney

Characteristic clinical findings

(ABCDEF)

A - Anemia with basophilic stippling

B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)

C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

E - Encephalopathy- Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsions, and coma

F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)
Diagnosis Blood lead levels
Treatment Calcium EDTA; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: You conduct a study to determine the association between computer use and visual impairment and get a correlation coefficient of +0.4. Which of the following scattergrams best represents your findings?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario having a correlation coefficient of +0.4 shows a positive weak correlation and the scattergram that best represents this finding is graph number 2.

Correlation is used to assess the strength and direction of the association between two variables (such as smoking and lung cancer). The correlation coefficient (denoted by r) is represented by a plus or minus sign, followed by a number (Example: -0.88). The correlation coefficient ranges from -1 to +1.

The numerical indicates the strength of correlation:

  • Correlation coefficients greater than ± 0.5 are considered strong and are likely to establish (if positive correlation) or disprove (if negative correlation) the association between two factors.
  • Correlation coefficients between 0 and ± 0.5 are regarded as weak.

The sign indicates the direction of the correlation.

  • Plus sign (+) suggests that both the variables being studied are positively correlated. This means that the high value of one variable is associated with a high value in another. An example is an association between salt intake and blood pressure readings.
  • Minus sign (-) suggests that both the variables being studied are negatively correlated. A high value of one variable such as cigarette consumption is associated with a low value of another variable such as life expectancy.

The relationship between two correlated variables can be represented graphically in the form of a scattergram. Each point represents one observation including both the variables and so would be equal to the sample size.

The following image shows the scattergram plotted for different values of the correlation coefficient:

To combine correlations of two or more samples, averaging methods can be used. It is recommended only when several different samples are independently drawn from the same population and the interest is in aggregating those values.

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson coefficient
  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

The option showing 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B shows the correctly matched vaccines with their adverse reactions.

questions.text:
During a medical camp at a school, you record the visual acuity of a child to be 6/30 for distant vision. According to ICD 11, which category of visual impairment does the child fall under?

ICD 11- International Classification of Disease 11
questions.solution:
A child having a visual acuity of 6/30 for distant vision falls under moderate distant vision impairment according to ICD 11 classification.

Classification of visual impairment according to the International Classification of Disease 11 (2018):

  • Distance vision impairment:
    • Mild - Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/12
    • Moderate - Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/18
    • Severe - Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/60
    • Blindness - Presenting visual acuity worse than 3/60
  • Near vision impairment:
    • Presenting near vision acuity worse than N6 or N8 at 40cm with existing correction.

Blindness: According to WHO, blindness is defined as visual acuity of less than 3/60, or a corresponding visual field loss to less than 10°, in the better eye with the best possible correction.

questions.text: While calculating the dependency ratio for a certain demographic population, an epidemiologist concludes that the particular population is at a demographic bonus. Which of the following is true about the population under evaluation?

choices.text: Decline in dependency ratio and increase in life expectancy
Rise in dependency ratio and decrease in fertility
Rise in dependency ratio and increase in life expectancy
Decline in dependency ratio and decrease in fertility

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, demographic bonus refers to the decline in dependency ratio due to declining fertility.

Dependency ratio:

In any given population, persons above the age of 65 years and children below the age of 15 years are considered as dependents. The total dependency ratio is the ratio of the combined dependent population to those in the age group of 15 – 65 years and is calculated using the formula given below:

Total dependency ratio = (Total population below 15 years and above 65 years) x 100/Total population in the age group of 15 – 64 years.

It is also called societal dependency ratio.

The total dependency ratio can also be divided into young age dependency ratio and old-age dependency ratio. Potential support ratio is the number of persons aged 15 to 64 years per older person aged 65 or more. This is the inverse of the old age dependency ratio.

Other important terms based on dependency ratio:

  • The term demographic bonus denotes the decline in dependency ratio due to declining fertility.
  • The term demographic burden is used to denote the increase in total dependency ratio during any period of time mostly caused by increased old-age dependency ratio.

questions.text:
A 14-month-old child with diarrhea is feeding well and is thirsty. Skin pinch when done returns in 2 seconds. Which of the following is appropriate for the management of this child in the first 4 hours?

ORS- Oral rehydration solution
questions.solution:
According to the IMNCI classification, the baby has 'some dehydration' and should be managed according to Plan B. The treatment under Plan B for a 14-month-old baby (1-2 years old) is 600-800 ml of ORS at home to be given in the first four hours.

Plan B:

Fluid and zinc supplementation is given to the child.

In addition to this, 50-100 ml extra fluid is given after each loose stool.

After four hours, the baby is reassessed and the appropriate plan is selected again for the continuation of the treatment.

The four rules of home treatment are:

  • Give extra fluid.
  • Give zinc supplements (1 tablet per day for 14 days, dissolved in a small amount of ORS, breast milk and clean water).
  • Continue breastfeeding.
  • Counsel the mother to return if there is blood in stools and if the child is feeding poorly.

Related Pearl: Comparison between low-osmolar oral rehydration solution and ReSoMal

questions.text: A target group is being tested by three screening tests for breast cancer as a part of a research program. The patient is considered diseased if she tests positive in all of the screening tests. Which of the following is false about this combination of screening tests?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario where the patient is considered diseased only if she is positive on all three tests, the combination of screening tests is said to be in series. The false statement is that it has high sensitivity. The net sensitivity is low for a screening test conducted in series.

The combination of two or more tests performed together can help to enhance the efficacy of detecting the presence or absence of disease. There are two principal forms of combination of tests:

Screening tests used in series:

  • If a patient is considered to have a disease when he is positive by every test conducted, then the tests are said to be in series.
  • If the patient tests negative in any one or more of the tests, they are classified as non-diseased.
  • It is thus difficult to classify a patient as diseased and easier to classify a patient as non-diseased.
  • With a decrease in sensitivity, there is an increase in the number of false negatives. This higher number of false negatives lowers the sensitivity.

Screening tests used in parallel:

  • If a patient is considered to have a disease when he is positive by any one or more tests, then the tests are said to be in parallel.  
  • Only if the patient tests negative on all the tests, they are classified as non-diseased.
  • Hence, some without disease are more likely to be wrongly classified into the diseased group, but many without disease are correctly excluded.
  Tests in Series Tests in parallel
Combined sensitivity Decreases Increases
Combined specificity Increases Decreases
Combined PPV Increases Decreases
Combined NPV Decreases Increases

Sensitivity is the ability of the test to correctly identify all individuals with the disease. It corresponds to the true positive cases out of a total diseased population.

Specificity is the ability of a test to correctly identify all individuals without the disease. It corresponds to the true-negative cases out of a total disease-free population.

The predictive tests are indicative of the validity of the tests and reflect the diagnostic value. A positive predictive value refers to the cases truly positive for the disease out of the total positive cases. A negative predictive value refers to the cases truly negative for the disease out of the total negative cases. 

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

questions.text: A statistician collects data regarding life expectancy at birth, mean and expected years of schooling, and the per capita income of the population. Which among the following is most likely being calculated by the statistician?
questions.solution:
The index that is calculated using the given indicators such as life expectancy at birth, mean and expected years of schooling, and the per capita income is the Human Developmental Index (HDI).

Human Development Index (HDI) is defined as a composite index focusing on three basic dimensions of human development. It assesses abilities 

  • To lead a healthy long life - measured by life expectancy at birth
  • To acquire knowledge- measured by mean years of schooling
  • To achieve a decent standard of living- measured by gross national income per capita

Hence the 3 dimension indices used to calculate the human development index are as follows life expectancy index, education index, and gross national index. 

Other options:

Option A- Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) uses three indicators which include infant mortality, life expectancy at age one, and literacy rate.

Option B- Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) is an international measure of acute multidimensional poverty by capturing the acute deprivations in health, education, and living standards that a person faces simultaneously. It is assessed using 3 dimensions and 10 indicators which are as follows:

  1. Health - Nutrition and child mortality
  2. Education- Years of schooling and school attendance
  3. Standard of living - 
    • Cooking fuel
    • Sanitation
    • Drinking water
    • Electricity
    • Housing
    • Assets

Option C- Disability-adjusted life years (DALY) is the amount of time lost due to ill health. It is expressed as the number of years lost due to ill health, disability, or early death. The components of DALY are:

  • Years of life lost due to premature death
  • Years lived with disability (YLD)
  • Years lived in a state of less than full health

Related Pearl: HDI vs. PQLI

 

Human Development Index (HDI)

 Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI)
Components

Longevity (Life expectancy at birth)

A decent standard of living (Real GNI per capita in PPP US$)

Knowledge (mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling)

Life expectancy at 1 year of age 

Infant Mortality rate

Literacy rate
Range 0 to +1 0 to 100

questions.text:
As a member of the RNTCP, you recruit a few laboratory technicians for the IRL. Which level of the RNTCP does the IRL belong to?

RNTCP: Revised National Tuberculosis Control Program
IRL: Intermediate reference laboratories
questions.solution:
The IRL belong to the level of state tuberculosis (TB) cell.

IRL is designated in either the state tuberculosis training and demonstration centres (STDC), public health laboratory, or medical college of the respective state. The functions are: 

  • Supervision and monitoring of quality assessment activities, mycobacterial culture and DST, and drug resistance surveillance (DRS).
  • Ensures the ability of staff in performing smear microscopy and provides technical training to laboratory technicians and laboratory supervisors.
  • On-site evaluation and panel testing once a year of all districts in the state.

The RNTCP was formed as the most cost-effective and systematic approach to strengthen the TB control programme in India. It adopted the internationally recommended directly observed treatment short-course (DOTS) strategy. 

The organogram of RNTCP is shown below:

Newer initiatives taken by RNTCP are: 

  • Nikshay - web-based application developed for TB surveillance
  • TB notification - it has been made mandatory that all health care workers should notify every TB case to the local authority
  • Ban on TB serology - the serological tests that have poor specificity are banned to use for the diagnosis of TB
  • Direct benefit transfer schemes - linking patients registered in Nikshay with AADHAAR for delivering benefits effectively to TB patients

RNTCP has been revised by the government of India as NTEP (national tuberculosis elimination program). The vision and goals of the NTEP program are:

  • Tuberculosis-free India with zero deaths, diseases, and poverty due to tuberculosis
  • To achieve a rapid decline in morbidity and mortality of TB cases while working towards the elimination of TB in India by 2025

NTEP has categorized and prioritized the districts in the country based on the following criteria to intensify tuberculosis control.

Categorization

Criteria

Category

High TB

Total TB case notification rate > 180 per lakh

A

High TB-HIV (Tuberculosis and HIV co-infected patients)

>10% proportion of known HIV positives amongst TB patients tested for HIV

B

High DR-TB (Drug-resistant tuberculosis)

> 25% proportion of relapse out of incident smear-positive TB cases

C
Very low case finding effort  Annual TB suspect examination rate of < 400 per lakh population D
Average None of above E
High case finding but Low TCNR Annual suspect examination rate >1200 per lakh population and total case notification rate < 80 per lakh population F

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments

6 months long

Oral drugs only
BPaLM regime (New MDR regime by WHO) Bdq Pa Lzd Mfx for 6 months

6 months long
9- 11 months shorter oral bedaquiline regime (Shorter MDR)

Intensive Phase:

Lfx Bdq(6 months) Cfz Z Hh E Eto for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Lfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

9-11 months long totally

Injectables used in Intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months or longer) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs 

18-20 months long

Oral drugs only

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

 

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug Resistant TB regimen:

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria

BPaLM regimen (New MDR TB regimen by WHO)

  2. Those with confirmed pulmonary TB and all forms of extrapulmonary TB (except for TB involving CNS, osteoarticular, and miliary TB).
  3. Patients >14 years of age.

  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV

  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z

questions.text:
As the medical officer of a PHC, you are tasked with managing the COVID-19 vaccination drive in your jurisdiction with a management method based on behavioral sciences. Which of the following techniques cannot be used?

PHC - Primary healthcare center.
questions.solution:
Work sampling cannot be used. It is a quantitative method of management, whereas all the other options mentioned above are management methods based on behavioral sciences.

Management is the purposeful and effective use of resources such as manpower, materials, and finances for the fulfillment of a pre-determined objective. They consist of four basic activities: planning, organizing, communicating, and monitoring.

The WHO has emphasized the need for improving the efficiency of the health care systems by applying modern management methods and techniques which are of two types -

  • Methods based on behavioral sciences
    • Organizational design
    • Personnel management
    • Communication
    • Information systems
    • Management by objectives (MBO)

  • Quantitative methods: They are derived from the field of economics, operation research, and budgeting.
    • Cost-Benefit analysis
    • Cost-Effective analysis
    • Cost–Accounting
    • Input-Output analysis
    • Model
    • Systems analysis
    • Network analysis- Includes Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT) and Critical Path Method (CPM)
    • Planning–Programming–Budgeting System (PPBS)
    • Work sampling
    • Decision making

Work sampling refers to the systematic observation and recording of activities at predetermined or random intervals. It includes analyzing the type of activities performed and the time needed to do them.

questions.text: After an earthquake, several casualties are received at the emergency department. One of these patients complains of difficulty in breathing. A quick bedside X-ray reveals the following. Which color is assigned to the patient according to the triage color coding?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with difficulty breathing and the X-ray with the arrow pointing to an area of increased radiolucency is indicative of tension pneumothorax that is classified as red according to the triage color coding.

Radiological features of tension pneumothorax:

  • Area of increased lucency
  • Ipsilateral increased intercostal spaces
  • Contralateral shift of the mediastinum
  • Depression of the hemidiaphragm

Triage is used to classify the priority of treatment.

It is carried out at the site of the disaster to determine the priority for immediate medical attention, transportation, and admission to the hospital.

Triage includes rapid classification of the injured based on their injuries and the chances of survival with prompt medical intervention. It provides maximum benefit to the greatest number of injured in a disaster situation. Higher priority is given to victims whose prognosis would be good with simple medical care. Lower priority is given to moribund patients who would have questionable benefits even with medical attention.

The internationally accepted four-color coded system is used commonly. It includes:

  • Red - High priority attention or transfer; Critical, but likely to survive if treatment is given early
  • Yellow - Medium priority; Critical, likely to survive if treatment is given within hours
  • Green - Ambulatory patients; Stable, likely to survive even if treatment is delayed for hours to days
  • Black - Dead or moribund patients; Not breathing, pulseless, so severely injured that no medical care is likely to help

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text:
A resident doctor gets pricked with a needle while attending to a patient suspected to have hepatitis B infection. The resident doctor has undergone two series of vaccination for hepatitis B virus (3-dose vaccination series). He has an anti-HBV titer of 8 mIU/mL after the second round of vaccination. Which of the following regimen will be administered as post-exposure prophylaxis?

HBIG: Hepatitis B hyperimmune globulin

choices.text: One dose of HBIG and revaccination
Two doses of HBIG only, each one month apart

questions.solution:
The resident doctor is considered as a non-responder because he has an anti-HBV titre of <10 mIU/ml after 6 doses of HBV vaccine (two 3-dose vaccination series). He must be administered two doses of HBIG, each one month apart.

Post-exposure prophylaxis for HBV:

When the Hepatitis B status of the source patient is unknown: HCW is managed as if the source patient were HBsAg-positive.

When the source patient is HBV-positive:

  • HCW whose response is unknown after one round of HBV vaccination - HBIG (hepatitis B hyperimmune globulin) 0.06 ml/kg as soon as possible, preferably within 24 hours and should simultaneously reinitiate the course of HBV immunization with three doses of hepatitis B vaccine.
  • HCW is a non-responder after two rounds of HBV vaccination - HBIG (hepatitis B hyperimmune globulin) 0.06 ml/kg as soon as possible, preferably within 24 hours and a second dose of HBIG, 1 month after the first dose.
  • Healthcare worker (HCW) is immunized and a responder (anti-HBs antibodies >10 mIU/ml) - They are protected. No need for hepatitis B immunoglobulin after a potential or confirmed exposure to hepatitis B.
  • HCW is incompletely vaccinated/unvaccinated - HBIG (hepatitis B hyperimmune globulin) 0.06 ml/kg as soon as possible, preferably within 24 hours and should simultaneously start/reinitiate the course of HBV immunization with three doses of hepatitis B vaccine.

 

Follow-up: After the three-dose vaccination series is completed, antibodies to the surface antigen is checked 1–2 months later. If the titres are <10 mIU/ml a second three-dose vaccine series is started or the HCW is checked for HBsAg positivity.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the primary health center for a routine medical check-up. What is the dosage of iron and folic acid supplementation to be given to her, under the Anemia Mukth Bharath initiative?

choices.text: 20 mg elemental iron + 100 mcg folic acid bi-weekly
45 mg elemental iron + 400 mcg folic acid weekly
60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid weekly
60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid daily

questions.solution:
According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat initiative, children between 5-9 years of age need to take 45 mg elemental iron + 400 mcg folic acid tablets once a week. These tablets are sugar-coated, and pink in color.

Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme: 

This is an initiative that aims to strengthen the existing mechanisms and foster newer strategies for tackling anemia. It focuses on six target beneficiary groups, through six interventions and six institutional mechanisms to achieve their target by 2022.

Interventions:

  • Prophylactic iron and folic acid supplementation.
  • Deworming.
  • Intensified year-round Behaviour Change Communication Campaign (Solid Body, Smart Mind) including ensuring delayed cord clamping in newborns.
  • Testing of anemia using digital methods and point-of-care treatment.
  • Mandatory provision of Iron and Folic Acid fortified foods in government-funded health programs.
  • Addressing non-nutritional causes of anemia in endemic pockets, with a special focus on malaria, hemoglobinopathies, and fluorosis.

Beneficiaries:

  • Children, 6-59 months of age
  • Children, 5-9 years of age
  • Adolescent girls and boys, 10-19 years of age
  • Women of reproductive age, 20-49 years of age
  • Pregnant women
  • Lactating mothers, 0-6 months

Institutions through which activities are carried out:

  • Intra-Ministerial Coordination
  • National Anemia Mukt Bharat Unit
  • National Centre of Excellence and Advanced Research on Anemia Control (NCEAR-A)
  • Convergence with other Ministries
  • Strengthening Supply Chain and Logistics
  • Anemia Mukt Bharat Dashboard and Digital Portal

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme, giving IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of their anemia status, is a key intervention.

questions.text: The following type of representation of data is used for what kind of variables?
questions.solution:
The image given above shows a histogram that is used to represent frequency distributions of continuous quantitative data.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: According to the Factories Act, 1948, a safety officer should be employed if the number of workers is more than _________.
questions.solution:
According to the Factories Act, 1948, a safety officer should be employed if the number of workers is more than 1000.

The Factories Act, 1948 states the following regarding safety and welfare measures:

  • > 1000 workers – there should be a safety officer
  • > 500 workers – there should be a welfare officer
  • > 250 workers – a canteen should be provided
  • > 30 female workers- a crèche should be provided

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: The given instrument is designed to measure ______.
questions.solution:
The given instrument is a dry and wet hygrometer and is designed to measure humidity. 

It consists of 2 similar thermometers beside each other. The dry bulb thermometer measures the dry bulb air temperature, and the wet bulb thermometer is kept moist with a wet muslin cloth covered over it. When both the temperature readings are equal, it signifies there is 100% saturation of the atmosphere with moisture. After obtaining both the readings, the relative humidity is calculated using psychrometric charts.

Other options:

Option A - Air velocity is calculated using anemometers. It consists of 4 hemispherical cups, attached to 2 crossed metal arms. The velocity of the wind is indicated on a counter called a cyclometer, placed on the anemometer. Kata thermometers are used as anemometers for low air velocities. 

Option C - Air pressure/Atmospheric pressure is measured using barometers.

Option D -  Air Quality Index (AQI) is complex air quality data of various pollutants that are compiled to give a single score (index value), nomenclature, and color that determines the air pollution of that particular location. 

Related Pearl: Humidity

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

Relative humidity (RH):

  • It is the ratio of the actual water vapor content to the maximum water vapor content in the air required for saturation of air at a given temperature and pressure. It is expressed as a percentage.
  • RH = Actual water vapor content x 100/ Total water vapor content
  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections. 

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers - most widely used instrument
  • Sling or whirling psychrometers

The following image depicts a whirling psychrometer:

The following image depicts an Assmann psychrometer:

The following image depicts a dry and wet hygrometer:

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: Hemoglobin levels were measured in 200 pregnant women. The results showed a mean hemoglobin level of 10.5 g/dL with a standard deviation of 0.5 g/dL. Assuming that the distribution is normal, how many women will have hemoglobin levels <9.5 g/dL?
questions.solution:
In the given population, 5 women will have hemoglobin (Hb) levels < 9.5 g/dL.

In a normal distribution, the distribution of values around the mean is as follows:

  • 68% of the distribution falls within ±1 SD of the mean. 
  • 95% of the distribution falls within ±2 SD of the mean. 
  • 99.7% of the distribution falls within ±3 SD of the mean.

In a normal distribution, 2 SD from the mean will have 95% of the participants. Therefore, 95% of pregnant women will have Hb levels of 10.5±2*0.5 = 10.5±1 =  9.5-11.5 g/dL.

The remaining 2.5% of women will have Hb >11.5 g/dL and 2.5% of women will have Hb level <9.5 g/dL.

2.5% of 200 = 5. Hence, 5 women will have Hb of <9.5 g/dL.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text:
A woman in her second trimester comes to the PHC for her regular check-up. You give her advice regarding her nutritional requirement. How much should the increase be in her caloric intake per day?

PHC: Primary health care
questions.solution:
The caloric intake per day should be increased to 340 Kcal/day for a woman in her second trimester. 

Pregnancy requires an additional 80,000 kcal during the last 20 weeks. This intake is not equally divided during pregnancy. It is divided as 0, 340, and 452 kcal/day added to the estimated non-pregnant energy requirements in the first, second, and third trimesters, respectively. 

During the first six months of lactation, an increase of 600 Kcal/day is recommended, and from 7-12 months of lactation, an addition of 520 Kcal/day is recommended.

Pregnancy is a period where a mother will require additional nutritional requirements to support the healthy growth and development of the fetus. According to the recommended dietary allowances by the Indian council of medical research (ICMR):

questions.text: The COVID-19 outbreak is a type of ______________.
questions.solution:
This outbreak of COVID-19 is an example of a propagated epidemic.

The propagated epidemic results from a person to person transmission of the infectious agent over a prolonged duration of time. In this scenario, the cases of COVID occurred over a period which is more than one incubation period of the disease. Other examples of a propagated epidemic include Hepatitis A and Polio.

If the period of the outbreak falls within one incubation period, then the type of epidemic is single exposure from a point source.

Difference between single exposure and multiple exposures epidemics:

  Point source, single exposure epidemic Point source, multiple exposure epidemic
Nature of exposure Single, brief exposure Multiple, continuous or intermittent exposures for a prolonged time
Nature of epidemic Explosive with clustering of cases within a short interval of time Less chance of clustering of cases within a short interval of time
Duration of epidemic Falls within one incubation period of a particular disease Extends beyond one incubation period of a particular disease
Example An epidemic of food poisoning  Outbreak of cholera

 

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy. Its types include:

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated or progressive epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: A hypertensive patient died of respiratory distress due to pneumonia caused by COVID-19 (test positive). What should be recorded in the line I (c) of the death certificate?
questions.solution:
COVID-19 will be filled in line I (c) of the death certificate, as it is the condition that gave rise to the antecedent cause (pneumonia).

In this patient:

  • I(a)- Disease directly leading to death: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
  • I(b)- Antecedent cause: Pneumonia
  • I(c)- Condition which gave rise to antecedent cause: COVID-19

Line II is used to record the contributory factors/causes such as diabetes or hypertension.

ICD allows identifying COVID-19 as the underlying cause of death. COVID-19 should be reported in a sequence ending with a terminal condition such as acute respiratory distress syndrome.

Other scenarios:

1. In case of pregnancy, puerperium, or birth leading to death in conjunction with COVID-19, record the sequence of events as usual.

For example: 

  • I(a)- Acute respiratory distress syndrome
  • I(b)- Pneumonia
  • I(c)- Pregnancy complicated by COVID-19

2. If an HIV patient is dead due to ARDS caused by COVID-19

  • I(a)-Acute respiratory distress syndrome
  • I(b)- COVID-19
  • Line II (co-morbidities)- HIV disease

3. Note that COVID-19 patients may die of other diseases or accidents, such cases are not deaths due to COVID-19 and should not be certified as such. In case you think COVID-19 aggravated the consequences of the accident/disease, it may be reported in part II.

Related Pearl: WHO Format for International Death Certificate

questions.text: In a primary health center, a nurse asks you about using a polio vaccine vial which has not crossed its expiry date. You look at the vaccine vial monitor (VVM) and tell her that it can be used. What did the VVM most likely show?

choices.text: Inner square white, outer circle blue
Inner square blue, outer circle white
Outer square white, inner circle blue
Outer square blue, inner circle white

questions.solution:
The vaccine vial monitor has most likely showed inner square white and outer circle blue.

The standard polio vaccine vial monitor has a colour monitor or labels on the vaccine bottles. The label has an inner white square and an outer blue circle.

It can be used if the inner square is lighter than the outer circle. When the colour of the inner square becomes that of the circle, it means that the vaccine has been exposed to a higher temperature and it cannot be used. 

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.
