questions.text: A 32-year-old working woman is pregnant, she already has 2 surviving children. According to the Maternity Act 2017, what duration of paid leave would she receive?
questions.solution:
According to Maternity Act 2017, a working mother who already has 2 surviving children will be given a paid leave for a maximum duration of 12 weeks of which not more than 6 weeks precedes the expected date of delivery.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: A study is performed where the mothers of both low birth weight (LBW) and normal birth weight babies are questioned regarding their intake of oral hypoglycemic agents (OHA) during the 1st trimester to determine the association of LBW and OHA intake in the first trimester. Which measure of association is appropriate for this study?
questions.solution:
The study design mentioned is a case-control study design to evaluate the strength of association between a risk factor and outcome. Hence, the best-suited measure would be the odds ratio.

Note that because the proportion of people in a case-control study who have the disease is determined by the researcher’s choice, and not by the actual proportion in the population, such studies cannot determine the incidence or prevalence of a disease, so they cannot determine the risk of contracting a disease. However, the strength of the association between a risk factor and the disease can still be evaluated with a case-control study, by examining the proportions of the people with and without the disease who had and had not, been exposed to the risk factor.

Other options:

Option A - Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates of disease (or death) between an exposed group and the non-exposed group. It is often expressed as a percentage. The terms "risk difference" or "cumulative incidence difference" refers to attributable risk.

Option C - Relative risk (RR) is the ratio of the incidence of the disease (or death) among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed.

Option D - Population-attributable risk is the incidence of the disease (or death) in the total population minus the incidence of disease (or death) among those who were not exposed to the suspected causal factor. Population attributable risk is measured by multiplying attributable risk with the population prevalence of exposure.

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Calculation of odds ratio (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where, 

  Cancer
Exposure   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d
  • OR < 1 indicates possible protection (negative association) as the frequency of exposure is lower among cases than controls.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.
  • OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: You are a newly posted factory medical officer and you observe that the factory doesn't have proper ventilation which is not good for its workers. After your suggestion, the factory officials deploy the use of centrifugal fans and exhaust fans for proper ventilation. This type of ventilation is called _______.
questions.solution:
The mechanical system of ventilation which employs both plenum ventilation (centrifugal fans) and exhaust ventilation (exhaust fans), is called balanced ventilation.

Types of ventilation:

Natural ventilation:

  • Wind:
    • Perflation is the ventilation of a space achieved by allowing wind to blow through it and removing the obstacles for this to happen (e.g., opening windows and doors)
    • Cross-ventilation is when air is allowed a natural path through space by providing openings at appropriate places, such as opposite to each other
  • Diffusion is the passage of air through small spaces or openings.
  • Inequality of temperature: Hot air rises and passes through openings provided high up in the room while cold/cool air passes through inlets placed low. This is exploited by the placement of windows, doors, skylight, and ventilators.

The drawback of natural ventilation is that the regulation of air quality is not possible.

Mechanical ventilation:

  • Exhaust ventilation utilizes exhaust fans that run on electricity and are placed high up near the roof on the external walls. A vacuum is created by which fresh air enters the ventilated space.
  • Plenum ventilation uses centrifugal fans to blow fresh air into the room and create a positive pressure, by which vitiated air is pushed out.
  • Balanced ventilation is the combination of both exhaust and plenum methods of ventilation.
  • Air conditioning is the simultaneous control of all or at least three factors that influence air quality in a confined room or space. These factors include temperature, humidity, air movement, distribution, dust, bacteria, odors and toxic gases.

questions.text: A child with bilateral cataracts, hearing loss, and known congenital heart defect was brought to the community health center with the following lesions that are present since birth. These are referred to as ______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of congenital rubella syndrome and the image shows blueberry muffin lesions which are characteristically associated with this syndrome.

The detrimental outcomes seen with Rubella infection in 1st trimester include:

  • Abortions
  • Stillbirth
  • Skin lesions: Blueberry muffin lesions
  • Triad of congenital rubella syndrome
    • Sensorineural deafness
    • Congenital heart defects – most common is patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)
    • Cataracts

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: While working in a family planning center, you have been advising couples regarding contraceptive methods. The curious interns ask you to explain the pearl index mentioned in a learning poster in the clinic. Which of the following points related to this would be incorrect?

choices.text: It is a method to measure the contraceptive efficacy
Total accidental pregnancies do not include abortions
Four months are deducted from total months of exposure for abortion
The number 1200 indicates the number of months in 100 years

questions.solution:
The option stating "Total accidental pregnancies do not include abortions" is the incorrect statement.

Total accidental pregnancies include every form of conception, like live births, stillbirths, or abortions, or the pregnancy that has not yet been terminated.

Pearl index:

It is defined as the number of "failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY)." It is a method used to measure contraceptive efficacy. This rate is given by the formula - 

Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure.

Other options:

Total months of exposure in the denominator is calculated after deducting 10 months for a full-term pregnancy, and 4 months for an abortion.

The number 1200 in the formula indicates the number of months in 100 years.

There is a decline in failure rates with increasing duration of use with most methods of contraception but the Pearl index is usually based on a specific exposure (usually one year) and, therefore, fails to accurately compare methods at various durations of exposure.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: You are a medical officer actively spearheading the sexually transmitted diseases control program in your block. As part of this, the sexual partners of the diagnosed patients are identified, located, investigated, and treated for the disease. This type of case detection that is employed by your team is  called ___________.
questions.solution:
The method of case detection in control of STDs when the sexual partners of the diagnosed patients are identified, located, tested, and treated is contact tracing.

Methods employed in case of detection of STDs are

  • Screening is done by testing apparently healthy volunteers from the general population. This helps in early detection of disease.
  • Contact tracing refers to identifying and locating sexual partners of diagnosed patients in order to investigate and treat them.
  • Cluster testing is done by asking the patients to name other persons of either sex who are part of the same socio-sexual environment.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman in her third trimester is diagnosed with uncomplicated malaria and her blood smear was found to be positive for plasmodium falciparum. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Falciparum malaria during the second and third trimesters of pregnancy should be treated with Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT).

Treatment of uncomplicated P. falciparum malaria during the first trimester of pregnancy consists of Quinine. Quinine can induce hypoglycemia, so pregnant patients are advised to eat regularly while on this treatment regimen. During the second and third trimesters, area-specific ACT is the preferred treatment option. 

  • For all states except north-eastern states: Artesunate and Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine
  • For north-eastern states: Artemether and Lumefantrine

Chloroquine (option C) is used for the treatment of P. vivax malaria during pregnancy. Primaquine (option D) is contraindicated in pregnant patients.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman at 14 weeks of gestation presents with vaginal discharge. She has no other complaints. On examination, greenish frothy discharge is present. No laboratory facilities are available. How would you proceed with management?

choices.text: Local treatment with clotrimazole vaginal pessary
Give oral secnidazole to the patient
Treat the patient and her husband with acyclovir

questions.solution:
The patient should be administered a single dose of secnidazole 2g orally as she has trichomonas vaginitis in her second trimester of pregnancy.

 

This patient in her second trimester of pregnancy has greenish, frothy vaginal discharge that is suggestive of trichomoniasis. However, since laboratory tests are not available, they cannot be confirmed. Using the syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections, she should be treated with oral secnidazole.

An alternate option is to use Tab. Tinidazole 500 mg orally twice daily for 5 days.

Metronidazole pessary is preferred in the first trimester of pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: The larval stage of a mosquito is given below. Which of the following is false regarding this species of mosquitoes?

choices.text: Has siphon tube in larval stage
Wings are spotted in adult mosquitoes
These mosquitoes are vectors for malaria
Their eggs are laid singly, not in clusters

questions.solution:
The image shown is of an Anopheles larva, which can be identified as it lies parallel to the undersurface of water. It doesn't have a siphon tube in its larval stage.

They lay the eggs singly and adult mosquitoes wings are spotted, whereas the other species of mosquitoes like Culex and mansonia lay eggs in clusters (except aedes) and their wings in the adult form are unspotted.

The Anopheles mosquitoes are vectors or carriers for malaria.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: A middle-aged man has been recently diagnosed with hypertension. He wants to try lifestyle changes before starting with pharmacological therapy. According to the rule of halves, where is he represented in the diagram, if A represents the whole population?
questions.solution:
According to the rule of halves, the person is represented in category C which represents people diagnosed with hypertension but not treated. This is because the patient has not yet started lifestyle management or pharmacotherapy.

Hypertension is a non-communicable chronic condition that is a risk factor for coronary heart disease, stroke, and other vascular complications. It is known to be an iceberg disease and the rule of halves is applied. The rule depicts the disease burden of hypertension in the community.

It states that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population are aware of the condition. Only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated.

Pictorial representation of the rule of halves in hypertension is shown below:

Hypertension can be prevented by primary and secondary prevention strategies. Primary prevention includes non-pharmacological measures such as lifestyle changes that are taken to reduce the incidence of the disease. It includes:

  • Population strategy approach aimed to reduce the incidence of the disease at the whole population level
  • High-risk strategy approach is done to identify high-risk individuals 

Secondary prevention includes pharmacological measures such as the usage of antihypertensives in affected individuals. It aims at early detection, adequate treatment, and follow-up of the patients to ensure proper compliance.

Note: Whenever hypertension can be classified into two different categories based on values of SBP and DBP, then the higher category is considered as the classification of hypertension.

Related Pearl: American Heart Association (AHA) 2019 guidelines for hypertension management

According to the AHA hypertension guidelines, 2019, pharmacologic treatment for hypertension is recommended

  • In patients who have ≥10% estimated 10year ASCVD risk, when BP ≥ 130/80 mmHg 
  • In patients who have <10% estimated 10year ASCVD risk when BP ≥ 140/90 mmHg 

 ASCVD - Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease

ASCVD risk is calculated using a calculator provided by the American Heart Association.

questions.text: A population survey recently reported a surge in xerophthalmia cases among children between 6 months to 6 years of age. The following options show the prevalence of certain indicators of vitamin A deficiency in the population at risk. Which of them signifies that vitamin A deficiency is a public health problem?

choices.text: Night blindness in >0.05% of the population
Bitot's spots in >0.5% of the population
Corneal scar in >0.01% of the population
Serum retinol less than 10 mcg/dL in >0.1% of the population

questions.solution:
Vitamin A deficiency is considered a public health problem if the prevalence rate of Bitot's spots is >0.5%, among several other criteria, in children between 6 months to 6 years of age.

To design an effective intervention program for the prevention of vitamin A deficiency, the first step is to identify the population risk. This is done by conducting population surveys or prevalence surveys that account for both clinical and biochemical criteria.

The surveys are done in preschool children between 6 months to 6 years of age. The following are the criteria, recommended by WHO to determine the public health significance of xerophthalmia and vitamin A deficiency.

Criteria 

Prevalence in population at risk(6 months to 6 years) 
Night blindness (XN) >1% 
Bitot’s spots  (X1B) >0.5% 

Corneal xerosis/ corneal ulcer/ Keratomalacia 

(X2/X3A/X3B)

 >0.01% 

Corneal scar

(XS)

 >0.05% 
Serum retinol (<10 mcg/dL)  >5% 

 

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: SPIKES protocol is for:
questions.solution:
SPIKES protocol is for breaking bad news.

Each letter represents a phase in the six-step sequence.

  • S - setting
  • P - perception
  • I - invitation or information
  • K - knowledge
  • E - empathy
  • S - summarizing or strategizing

Key components of the SPIKES strategy include:

  • Demonstrating empathy
  • Acknowledging and validating the patient's feelings
  • Exploring the patient's understanding and acceptance of the bad news
  • Providing information about possible interventions

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of sentinel surveillance?

choices.text: Indicates trends in the entire target population
Identifying cases that are free of disability

questions.solution:
Sentinel surveillance helps in identifying the missing cases among the old and new cases.

Sentinel surveillance is a method to identify the missing cases and hence supplement the notified cases.

The sentinel data collected in this type of surveillance can estimate the disease prevalence (old and new cases) in the total population. This system provides more valuable and detailed information compared to what is obtained from traditional notification systems.

In sentinel surveillance, a prearranged set of reporting sources agrees to report all the cases of a defined condition. This will indicate the trend of the disease in the entire target population.

 

Related Pearl: Sentinel Surveillance

  • Sentinel surveillance is used to augment the notification systems used in surveillance of diseases.
  • It detects the total case load and is used to identify the missing cases that are not notified among the old and new cases.
  • Sentinel data from the same is extrapolated to the entire population and the prevalence can be commented on.
  • Advantages: Bias in reporting is minimized and the feedback is simplified.
